revised_title: Kin Recognition and Brooding Behavior in Mountain Dusky Salamanders
tldr: This study investigates the kin recognition and brooding behavior in mountain dusky salamanders. Researchers found that females can specifically recognize and preferentially brood their own eggs over those of another conspecific. A significant correlation was discovered between the time spent brooding and genetic similarity determined by random amplification of polymorphic DNA (RAPD) analysis. This is the first demonstration of a quantitative relation between genetic relatedness and maternal care in amphibians, with implications for the nature of maternal kin recognition and its effect on kin-selective behavior in this class.
